In addition to estimating the contribution of micro-evolution, the red squirrel study provided the first measurement of the role of phenotypic plasticity in climate-induced development of a functional trait,
97 but it was not the first to document changes in phenology, that is the timing of seasonal events, in response to changing climatic conditions (see refs. 17, 24, 26, 28, 109). It still is the case that most known examples of phenotypic changes linked to climate change relate to phenology.
95 For example, in response to progressive environmental change over a 28-y period on the Isle of Rum, United Kingdom, red deer ( Cervus elaphus) have displayed phenotypic plasticity in the phenological traits of estrus date, parturition date, antler cast and clean date and the start and end of the rut, with most of the variation being attributable to earlier plant growth.
